meanings.def: to fix something to something else, usually with a sticky substance; to become fixed to something in this way
examples: stick something + adv./prep. He stuck a stamp on the envelope.
We used glue to stick the broken pieces together.
I stuck the photos into an album.
(+ adv./prep.) Her wet clothes were sticking to her body.
The glue's useless—the pieces just won't stick.
Her wet hair was sticking to her head.
I forgot to stick a stamp on the envelope.

meanings.def: to become fixed in one position and impossible to move
examples: This drawer keeps sticking.
stick in something The key has stuck in the lock.

meanings.def: to push something, usually a sharp object, into something; to be pushed into something
examples: stick something + adv./prep. The nurse stuck the needle into my arm.
Don't stick your fingers through the bars of the cage.
+ adv./prep. I found a nail sticking in the tyre.
He simply stuck a pin in at random among the names of the candidates.
She stuck a finger into the sugar bowl.
The little boy had stuck his head through the railings.

meanings.def: to put something in a place, especially quickly or carelessly
examples: Stick your bags down there.
He stuck his hands in his pockets and strolled off.
Can you stick this on the noticeboard?
Peter stuck his head around the door and said, ‘Coffee, anyone?’
He stuck the note through her letter box.
(informal) Stick 'em up! (= Put your hands above your head—I have a gun!)

meanings.def: used to say in a rude and angry way that you are not interested in what somebody has, offers, does, etc.
examples: I got sick of my boss's moaning and told him he could stick the job.

meanings.def: to accept a difficult or unpleasant situation or person
examples: stick something/somebody I don't know how you stick that job.
They’re always arguing—I can’t stick it any longer.
The problem is, my mother can't stick my boyfriend.
stick doing something John can't stick living with his parents.

meanings.def: to become accepted
examples: The police couldn't make the charges stick (= show them to be true).
His friends called him Bart and the name has stuck (= has become the name that everyone calls him).

meanings.def: to say that you will not take any more cards
people remember and believe the bad things they hear about other people, even if they are later shown to be false
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
examples: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

meanings.def: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to give your opinion, advice, etc. without being asked and when it is probably not wanted
examples: I was getting along very nicely until Patrick stuck his oar in.

meanings.def: to form the shape of a V with the two fingers nearest your thumb and raise your hand in the air with the back part of it facing somebody, done to be rude to them or to show them that you are angry
examples: She enjoys sticking two fingers up to convention.

meanings.def: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

meanings.def: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stood out a mile that she was lying.

meanings.def: to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
to attack somebody by criticizing them when they are in a difficult situation
examples: I wonder if the press will stick the boot in?

meanings.def: to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

meanings.def: to be difficult or impossible to say
examples: She wanted to say how sorry she was but the words seemed to stick in her throat.

meanings.def: to be difficult or impossible to accept; to make you angry
to do or say something when there is a risk that you may be wrong
examples: I’ll stick my neck out and say that Bill is definitely the best candidate for the job.

meanings.def: to try to become involved in something that should not involve you
examples: He's always sticking his nose into other people's business.

meanings.def: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stuck out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you'll stick out like a sore thumb.

meanings.def: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stuck out a mile that she was lying.

meanings.def: to refuse to change your mind about something even when other people are trying to persuade you that you are wrong
to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you

idioms.def: people remember and believe the bad things they hear about other people, even if they are later shown to be false
to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
examples: I wonder if the press will put the boot in?

idioms.idiom: put/stick the knife in | put/stick the knife into somebody
idioms.def: to behave towards somebody in an unfriendly way and try to harm them
to give your opinion, advice, etc. without being asked and when it is probably not wanted
examples: I was getting along very nicely until Patrick stuck his oar in.

idioms.idiom: put/stick two fingers up at somebody
idioms.def: to form the shape of a V with the two fingers nearest your thumb and raise your hand in the air with the back part of it facing somebody, done to be rude to them or to show them that you are angry
examples: She enjoys sticking two fingers up to convention.

idioms.idiom: stand/stick out like a sore thumb
idioms.def: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stood out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you’ll stand out like a sore thumb.

idioms.def: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stood out a mile that she was lying.

idioms.def: to kick somebody very hard, especially when they are on the ground
examples: I wonder if the press will stick the boot in?

idioms.def: to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

idioms.def: to be difficult or impossible to say
examples: She wanted to say how sorry she was but the words seemed to stick in her throat.

idioms.def: to do or say something when there is a risk that you may be wrong
examples: I’ll stick my neck out and say that Bill is definitely the best candidate for the job.

idioms.def: to try to become involved in something that should not involve you
examples: He's always sticking his nose into other people's business.

idioms.idiom: stick/stand out like a sore thumb
idioms.def: to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
examples: The blue building stuck out like a sore thumb among the whitewashed villas.
If you wear a suit to the party, you'll stick out like a sore thumb.

idioms.def: to be very obvious or easy to notice
examples: It stuck out a mile that she was lying.

idioms.def: to refuse to change your mind about something even when other people are trying to persuade you that you are wrong

idioms.idiom: tell somebody where to put/stick something | tell somebody what they can do with something
idioms.def: to make it clear to somebody that you are angry and are rejecting what they are offering you

meanings.def: a thin piece of wood that has fallen or been broken from a tree
examples: We collected dry sticks to start a fire.
He said he was beaten with a stick.
The boys were throwing sticks and stones at the dog.
Her arms and legs were like sticks (= very thin).

meanings.def: a stick that you carry and use as a support when you are walking
examples: He walks with a stick these days, but he still gets about.
The old lady leant on her stick as she talked.

meanings.def: a long, thin object that is used in some sports to hit or control the ball
examples: a hockey stick

meanings.def: a long, thin piece of something
examples: The man had sticks of dynamite strapped to his chest.
a stick of gum
carrot/cinnamon/celery sticks
(North American English) a stick of butter
The savoury dips were served with sticks of carrot and celery.

meanings.def: a thin piece of wood or plastic that you use for a particular purpose
examples: pieces of pineapple on sticks
The men were carrying spades and measuring sticks.
I used a selfie stick to take the picture.

meanings.def: a quantity of a substance, such as solid glue (= a sticky substance), that is sold in a small container with round ends and straight sides, and can be pushed further out of the container as it is used
a stick with a handle in a plane that is used to control direction or height
a handle used to change the gears of a vehicle
a baton, used by the person who conducts an orchestra
criticism or severe words
examples: The referee got a lot of stick from the home fans.

meanings.def: country areas, a long way from cities
examples: We live out in the sticks.

meanings.def: a person
examples: He's not such a bad old stick.

meanings.def: to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
the use or threat of force or power
examples: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

meanings.def: if you use the carrot and stick approach, you persuade somebody to try harder by offering them a reward if they do, or a punishment if they do not
examples: The emphasis is on the carrot of incentive rather than the stick of taxes.
to adopt the carrot-and-stick approach
He decided to use the carrot and stick approach.

meanings.def: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task
to understand something in the wrong way
a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He upped sticks and went back to France.

idioms.def: to be in a difficult situation when any action you take will have bad results
the use or threat of force or power
examples: The authorities used quiet persuasion instead of the big stick.

idioms.def: if you use the carrot and stick approach, you persuade somebody to try harder by offering them a reward if they do, or a punishment if they do not
examples: The emphasis is on the carrot of incentive rather than the stick of taxes.
to adopt the carrot-and-stick approach
He decided to use the carrot and stick approach.

idioms.idiom: get the short end of the stick
idioms.def: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task

idioms.idiom: get (hold of) the wrong end of the stick
idioms.def: to understand something in the wrong way

idioms.idiom: a rod/stick to beat somebody with
idioms.def: a fact, an argument, etc. that is used in order to blame or punish somebody
to suddenly move from your house and go to live somewhere else
examples: He upped sticks and went back to France.
